etymology.description: semantic: 金 (“metal; money”) + phonetic: 戔.
etymology.interpretation: 金 signals association with metal and, by extension, money and currency. 戔 supplies the phonetic value that led to the modern reading qián, while the overall form evokes a metal object used as money.
etymology.simplification: Simplified from 錢 by replacing 金 → 钅 and 戔 → 戋 to reduce strokes; same pattern as in 残.

examples.chinese: 他把零钱放进钱包里(他把零錢放進錢包裡)。
examples.pinyin: Tā bǎ língqián fàng jìn qiánbāo lǐ.
examples.english: He put the change into the wallet.

examples.chinese: 经济增长让很多人更有钱(經濟增長讓很多人更有錢)。
examples.pinyin: Jīngjì zēngzhǎng ràng hěn duō rén gèng yǒu qián.
examples.english: Economic growth makes many people wealthier.
